titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0899, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel of Matthew and of Mark in Armenian. Eusebian section numbers in the margins against the text. Concordance in the lower margins; and Pentecostal lection numbers. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 35.
Foliate vignettes in blue, red, and green (fols. 12r, 28v).

foliation.p: 1-28. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil.

collation.p: Quire numbers extant in the lower margins are those of quire 8 (fol. 1); quire 9 (fol. 9); quire 20 (fol. 13); quire 30 (fol. 21).

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 330 x 215 mm (fol. 8r ). Each column is 330 x 95 mm with a space of 25 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 21 lines. Ruling with hard point. Pricking in the inner and outer margins.

handDesc.p: Written in erkat’agir script in dark brown ink (some fading).

condition.p: Leaves moderately cockled. Inner edge of several leaves taped. All edges dry and corners damaged. Bottom portion of fol. 22 broken or cut off. Several section numbers overwritten. Additional numbers and frames in ink added on some leaves (see fol. 28v). Random dirt and grease stains.

binding.p: Bound in dark brown cloth over pasteboard. Spine and corners covered in tan leather. Pastedowns of paper.

origin.p: The manuscript to which the present leaves belonged is judged to have been written in either the 9th or 10th century. A place of origin is unknown.

provenance.p: Belonged to author and New Testament text critic Caspar René Gregory (1846-1917), and his brother, Professor William J. Gregory of Westminster, Colorado. Purchased by Chicago businessman Frederick T. Haskell (1854-1935) from William Gregory, ca. 1934.
Signature of Caspar René Gregory; content notation dated 1886; University of Chicago bookplate (front pastedown).

acquisition.p: Gift of Frederick T. Haskell to the University of Chicago, February or March 1935.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

vol. 3, p. 572. no. 45.

([Chicago:] s.n., 1952),
p. 22.
Erroll F. Rhodes, An Annotated List of Armenian New Testament Manuscripts, Annual Report of Theology 1 (1959), p. 134 (1037).

([Chicago: s.n., 1973]), 36, no. 37.

(Berkeley: University of California Press, 1976),
pp. 225-226.

(New York: Pierpont Morgan Library; Princeton, N.J.: distributed by Princeton University Press, 1994),
